Files.File Summary: Jim Kitchen, a civilian space explorer, describes his experience looking out the window of a spacecraft. He saw the curvature of the Earth, hundreds or thousands of miles in every direction, and was drawn to a dark, void-like area that was unlike the night sky. Time seemed to stand still as he gazed out the window, mesmerized by the vastness of the view.

It's not like night sky black, it's just dark and dark.
Void.

Files.File Summary: The engine ignites and the capsule is filled with fire, taking off at 2,000 miles per hour. Jim is stunned and quiet, looking at the Earth from the blackness of space. He describes the view as "mind-numbing" and "beautiful," with the planet's atmosphere appearing as a "little wisp." Jim reflects on how this moment is a fulfillment of his childhood dream, and encourages others to stay committed to their goals, as it took him 50 years to achieve his. He emphasizes that anyone can do it, as long as they keep their dream alive.

Files.File Summary: Jim is taking 10 passports with him to space, including one with the Ukrainian and American flags, which he plans to float around in space. He's also bringing personal trinkets, pictures of his family, and a signed UNC basketball by Michael Jordan and Dean Smith. The ball will be signed by other coaches and used for a meaningful purpose. Jim is looking forward to the experience, focusing on having fun, being present, and absorbing the moment. He's excited to take what he's learning back to his students and others.

Files.File Summary: The Astronaut Village is where Blue Origin crew members stay during training and before launch. The village is equipped with Airstreams, which are high-tech, luxurious trailers that serve as living quarters. The Airstreams are equipped with amenities such as a kitchen, bathroom, and sleeping quarters. The village also has a communal area where crew members can relax and socialize. The Airstream is designed to be self-sufficient, with its own power and water supply.

Files.File Summary: Jim Kitchen's training day began with a simulation of the launch sequence, where he experienced intense sounds and vibrations. He realized it was getting real when he understood the complexity of the launch process and the numerous things that could go wrong. He was struck by the sobering thought that many things had to work correctly for the mission to succeed. Today, he will repeat the launch sequence multiple times to make it routine on launch day. He will also develop a zero-G plan with his crew for the three and a half minutes of weightlessness.

Files.File Summary: Jim Kitchen's training for his space trip was physically and mentally exhausting, with a full day of training and 25 repetitions of scenarios and safety protocols. He enjoyed the training and felt prepared for the trip. Jim wrote three postcards to inspire future generations, one for students at the University of North Carolina, one for Mr. Putin, and one with a quote about the impossible becoming ordinary. He is excited for the trip and feels ready to go, despite the delay due to high winds. Jim is looking forward to experiencing awe in space and is planning to wear a diaper for the full experience. He is also planning to unfurl a 194 flag during the trip.

Files.File Summary: Jim Kitchen's training day began with a simulation of the launch sequence, where he experienced intense sounds and vibrations. He realized it was getting real when he understood the complexity of the launch process and the numerous things that could go wrong. He was struck by the sobering thought that many things had to work correctly for the mission to succeed. Today, he will repeat the launch sequence multiple times to make it routine on launch day. He will also develop a zero-G plan with his crew for the three and a half minutes of weightlessness.
